results.justification: A classic dark pop progression (i-VI-V-i) using the powerful V7 chord from the harmonic minor scale. The Dmaj7 offers a brief lift before the C#7 creates strong tension pulling back to the tonic, giving it a driving, dramatic feel.

This progression subverts a standard ii-V-i by replacing the expected tonic resolution with the relative major's subdominant (Dmaj7). This creates a quirky, perpetually unresolved loop that feels modern and slightly off-kilter.

This progression has a funky, propulsive feel due to the ascending bassline created by the first inversion F#m. It builds towards the relative major (A) using a secondary dominant (E7), giving it a brief moment of brightness before it would typically cycle back to the minor key.

The use of Gmaj7, the bII chord, introduces a dark, Phrygian mode flavor right after the tonic. The C#7sus4 resolving to C#7 is a classic tension-building device that adds grit and anticipation, perfect for a dark, moody chorus.

Utilizing the F# melodic minor scale, the powerful back-to-back major chords (B and C#) create an uplifting yet aggressive sound. This is immediately undercut by the tense and dissonant D#dim chord, creating a quirky and dramatic drop before resolving.

A simple but highly effective progression built on a descending bassline (F#-E-D-C#). This i-VII-VI-V movement is a staple in dark pop (like Bella Poarch) for its hypnotic, melancholic, and foreboding spiral downwards.

The F#m(maj7) chord immediately establishes a creepy, cinematic feel with its minor-third/major-seventh clash. The A-augmented chord continues this unsettling vibe, which is only briefly relieved by Dmaj7 before the E#dim7 creates maximum dissonance, begging to resolve back to the tonic.

This progression feels funky and syncopated. The F#m11 is a modern, jazzy tonic. The highlight is the E7(b9), a spicy dominant chord borrowed from the parallel harmonic major, which adds a dark, unexpected twist before the loop resets.

This progression avoids the F#m tonic entirely, creating a sense of floating or searching, reminiscent of 21 Pilots. While the chords are diatonic to F# minor (III-v-iv-VI), their sequence feels centered around A major, creating a quirky ambiguity that is poppy yet melancholic.

This progression is harmonically ambiguous and quirky. The A/B acts as a floaty Bsus chord, creating an unresolved feeling. It moves to a bright Emaj7 before the D#m7b5 (from melodic minor) yanks it back into a tense, dark space, preventing any simple resolution.
